channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: In a reversal, the Trump administration restores funding for women's health study
item.description: The unexpected elimination of funding for the decades-long research project focused on women's health shocked scientists. They were heartened by the quick restoration of support.
item.content:encoded:
The unexpected elimination of funding for the decades-long research project focused on women's health shocked scientists. They were heartened by the quick restoration of support.

(Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)
item.dc:creator: Rob Stein

item.title: DOGE dismantling foreign aid agency started by George W. Bush
item.description: The Millenium Challenge Corporation, focused on boosting economic growth abroad, could essentially shutter.
item.content:encoded:
The Millenium Challenge Corporation, focused on boosting economic growth abroad, could essentially shutter.

(Image credit: Samuel Corum/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Lambert

item.title: Americans are protesting the Trump administration. Do they work?
item.description:
When you think of a successful protest movement, most Americans probably think of the American Civil Rights movement, and the March on Washington in 1963.

Martin Luther King, Jr. standing behind a podium on the steps of the Lincoln memorial delivered his most famous speech and a line that would come to define the goals of the Civil Rights Movement.

President Lyndon Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act just nine months after the March. A year after that Johnson signed the National Voting Rights Act of 1965.

The quest for equality continues. In the decades since that bright summer day in August 1963, many other Americans have tried to use the model of protest to achieve their political goals.

But do protests work?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
When you think of a successful protest movement, most Americans probably think of the American Civil Rights movement, and the March on Washington in 1963.

Martin Luther King, Jr. standing behind a podium on the steps of the Lincoln memorial delivered his most famous speech and a line that would come to define the goals of the Civil Rights Movement.

President Lyndon Johnson signed the Civil Rights Act just nine months after the March. A year after that Johnson signed the National Voting Rights Act of 1965.

The quest for equality continues. In the decades since that bright summer day in August 1963, many other Americans have tried to use the model of protest to achieve their political goals.

But do protests work?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: Fotosearch)

item.title: A developing political scandal in Florida has Gov. Ron DeSantis on the defensive
item.description: A developing political scandal in Florida has put Gov. Ron DeSantis on the defensive. Republican lawmakers are investigating how $10 million in state money was diverted for use in a campaign.
item.content:encoded:
A developing political scandal in Florida has put Gov. Ron DeSantis on the defensive. Republican lawmakers are investigating how $10 million in state money was diverted for use in a campaign.

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
item.dc:creator: Greg Allen

item.title: What Is the Relationship Between Russia and the U.S. Now?
item.description:
The sometimes cold and often frozen relationship between Russia and the U.S. has gotten a lot warmer since President Trump took office. And even though the American drive to broker a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine may be faltering, the desire to do big business deals with the Kremlin has not. We go to Moscow to look at how the relationship between the two countries has changed, from the Russian perspective.

CORRECTION: A previous version of the audio in this story misidentified Pete Hegseth as the secretary of state. He is the secretary of defense.
item.content:encoded:
The sometimes cold and often frozen relationship between Russia and the U.S. has gotten a lot warmer since President Trump took office. And even though the American drive to broker a peace deal between Russia and Ukraine may be faltering, the desire to do big business deals with the Kremlin has not. We go to Moscow to look at how the relationship between the two countries has changed, from the Russian perspective.

CORRECTION: A previous version of the audio in this story misidentified Pete Hegseth as the secretary of state. He is the secretary of defense.
item.dc:creator: Charles Maynes

item.title: Artists wanted for Trump's National Garden of American Heroes
item.description: The National Endowment for the Humanities says the project will "honor the statesmen, visionaries, and innovators who shaped the nation." It's a lot of statues.
item.content:encoded:
The National Endowment for the Humanities says the project will "honor the statesmen, visionaries, and innovators who shaped the nation." It's a lot of statues.

(Image credit: Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Blair

item.title: More than 50 House Democrats demand answers after whistleblower report on DOGE
item.description: Members of the Congressional Labor Caucus wrote the letter after NPR reported that a whistleblower says DOGE may have removed sensitive labor data and compromised the security of computer systems.
item.content:encoded:
Members of the Congressional Labor Caucus wrote the letter after NPR reported that a whistleblower says DOGE may have removed sensitive labor data and compromised the security of computer systems.

(Image credit: Brendan Smialowski)
item.dc:creator: Jenna McLaughlin

item.title: Home sales just posted their biggest monthly fall since 2022
item.description: More inventory hitting the market was expected to drive sales. Instead, existing home sales suggest a continued slump in the housing market, with mortgage rates hurting affordability.
item.content:encoded:
More inventory hitting the market was expected to drive sales. Instead, existing home sales suggest a continued slump in the housing market, with mortgage rates hurting affordability.

(Image credit: David Zalubowski)
item.dc:creator: Laurel Wamsley

item.title: Judge pauses parts of Trump's sweeping executive order on voting
item.description: A federal judge has paused a key section of President Trump's executive order that makes sweeping changes to voting and elections.
item.content:encoded:
A federal judge has paused a key section of President Trump's executive order that makes sweeping changes to voting and elections.

(Image credit: Reba Saldanha)
item.dc:creator: Jude Joffe-Block

item.title: After nearly 50 years cooped up inside, Rockalina the turtle finds the great outdoors
item.description: Rockalina was an adult eastern box turtle living in the wild when she was taken into a New York home in 1977. When a reptile rehabilitation center got a hold of her this February, they worried for her survival.
item.content:encoded:
Rockalina was an adult eastern box turtle living in the wild when she was taken into a New York home in 1977. When a reptile rehabilitation center got a hold of her this February, they worried for her survival.

(Image credit: Garden State Tortoise)
item.dc:creator: Alina Hartounian
